title: 113_s1737
content: The "Minimum Wage Fairness Act" is the short title of the Act. It includes provisions for increasing the minimum wage. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to increase the minimum wage gradually over the course of three years, starting at $8.20 an hour and reaching a determination by the Secretary thereafter based on consumer price increases. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to determine the minimum wage annually based on the increase in the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to calculate the minimum wage based on the annual increase in the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers. The cash wage for tipped employees must not be less than a specified amount. The Minimum Wage Fairness Act sets hourly wage increases annually until reaching 70% of the wage in effect under section 6(a)(1) of the Fair Labor Standards Act. The Minimum Wage Fairness Act establishes yearly wage increases until reaching 70% of the wage under section 6(a)(1) of the Fair Labor Standards Act, with adjustments to maintain this percentage. Additionally, a notice must be published 60 days before any effective date. The Minimum Wage Fairness Act requires the Secretary of Labor to publish a notice 60 days before any increase in the minimum wage. The amendments made by the Act will take effect on the first day of the sixth month after enactment. SEC. 3.
